required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Ischemic Pre-Conditioning on the Rate of Recovery Following Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Ischemic Pre-Conditioning on the Rate of Recovery Following Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage: a Randomized Control Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
Strenuous exercise or exercise involving eccentric muscle contractions can lead to muscle damage and changes in muscle function; this is known as exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD). It is known that brief, repeated periods of ischemia followed by reperfusion, known as Ischemic Preconditioning (IPC) cause a delay in cell injury in cardiac muscle as well as in various other organs.
Therefore the purpose of this study is to:
1. Quantify the use of IPC in recovery following EIMD.
2. Identify any effect of IPC during recovery on muscle function

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in maximal voluntary contraction
primary_outcome.time_frame: pre exercise, 24 hours post, 48 hours post and 72 hours post exercise
primary_outcome.description: Isometric MVC of the participants' dominant knee extensors was assessed using a strain gauge. MVCs were performed for 3 s with a 60 s rest between each repetition. The change in MVC will be determined 24, 48 and 72 hours following pre exercise conditions.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Creatine kinase
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre exercise, 24 hours post, 48 hours post and 72 hours post exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Plasma CK was determined from an earlobe capillary blood sample. The sample (10 microlitres) was analysed immediately using an semi-automated clinical chemistry analyser. The change in CK will be determined 24, 48 and 72 hours following pre exercise conditions

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Limb girth
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre exercise, 24 hours post, 48 hours post and 72 hours post exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Mid-thigh and calf circumference was assessed as a measure of limb swelling using an anthropometric tape measure. Both measures were obtained with the participant in a standing position. The change in limb girth will be determined 24, 48 and 72 hours following pre exercise conditions

secondary_outcome.measure: Chnage from baseline in Vertical jump
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre exercise, 24 hours post, 48 hours post and 72 hours post exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Vertical jump (VJ) performance was assessed using an electronic timing mat with hands placed on hips and participants dropping down to a self-selected level before jumping maximally. The change in VJ will be determined 24, 48 and 72 hours following pre exercise conditions

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Muscle soreness
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre exercise, 24 hours post, 48 hours post and 72 hours post exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Muscle soreness - Participants were asked to perform and hold a squat (90Â° knee angle) whilst they rated their perceived muscle soreness on a 200 mm visual analogue scale. The scale consisted of a line from 0 mm (no pain) to 200 mm (unbearably painful). The change in muscle soreness will be determined 24, 48 and 72 hours following pre exercise conditions

arm_group.description: IPC (4 x 5 minute cycles @ 220 mmHg) with 5 min reperfusion between trials.
Placebo (4 x 5 minute cycles @ 20mmHg) with 5 minutes between each cycle

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Physically Active Males
Exclusion Criteria:
- Muscular skeletal disorders
